content:
Bill Gates je car PR-ja!

Evropa ga preganja zaradi njegovih (Microsoftovih) monopolističnih
taktik, on pa jim vrača na ta način.

Microsoft je za Slovenijo ena sama izguba - letno jim damo nekaj 10
mio EUR. Če bi ta denar namenili domačim podjetjem za razvoj
(nadgradnjo) odprtokodnega softverja, bi ustvarili precej visoko
tehnolških delovnih mest in še denar bi ostal doma.

Zgodbe o priložnosti za slovenska in EU podjetja, bla, bla.. pa so
čisto zavajanje. Edina "priložnost" je, da Microsoftu plačajo
licenco, nato razvijajo rešitve na njegovih platformah in postanejo
še bolj odvisni od teh platform, ter nadaljujejo plačevanje
licenc...

Upam, da EU uradniki, vključno z Potočnikom ne bodo nasedli.

ctx: Evropa potrebuje inovacije, Microsoft pa evropsko znanje in kadre
content:
Yeah, but who is going to make this thing actually work? That
brings us to the Novell/Microsoft interoperability lab, which was
also part of last week's agreement. The moment I read about that,
the question that popped into my mind was, "Which company will be
doing all the work?" If historical patterns kick in, it will be
Novell. As the smaller and leaner company Novell has always been
able to beat Microsoft on technology. This agreement will tie
Novell to interoperability promises Microsoft doesn't care about
nearly as much as Novell does, with the result that Novell will do
most of the work. We saw this happen before when 3Com tied its
fortunes to Microsoft in the late 1980s with the lamented
3Com-Microsoft LAN Manager network operating system, which was
ironically Microsoft's answer to Novell at that time. Then 3Com CEO
Bill Krause felt the only way to compete with Novell was through an
alliance with Microsoft. So 3Com bought its way into the
relationship, ended up doing all the work (MORE THAN all the work
if you count recoding Microsoft blunders), then had to BUY ITS WAY
BACK OUT when the product failed. After that deal was over and the
blood had dried, 3Com founder Bob Metcalfe claims that a Microsoft
exec told him, "You made a fatal error, you trusted us."


Treba je brati med vrsticami. Toliko o copy and paste.

Ma Q! En pa ta dovolj dober. apple zadnje čase kar rula
(nimam)

Sicer pa zabava. Sem bil zadnjič na enem MS dogodku v Pragi (SLK
AirLift),gre za produkt za eLearning (kao eCampus ) ki ga bo Microsoft splavil (sedaj je beta)
potem ga pa prepustil v prosti razvoj komur pač paše, se pravi open
source zadeva.

In ni vrag, da se oglasi en šolnik, in lepo vpraša, kako hudiča naj
se on sedaj odloči za upgrade iz ClassServerja na SLK, če pa ni
nobene garancije da bo se zadeva razvijala naprej.

Skratka tudi v šolskih krogih, se počasi zzavedajo kakšna je
razlika med open source in komercialnim softwerom. Na NT konferenci
mi je pa kolega iz enega malce resnejšega IT podjetja lepo
prijavil, da brezplačne zadeve za resno poslovno rabo pač ne
potegnejo. Ok, dokaj radikalno mnenje se mi je zdelo .... dokler
nisem potem videl, kaj pomeni ko rabiš support za linux, ker imaš
recimo konfiguracijo, ki je malce specifična (4 procesorji, 16 GB
RAMa, ...) in PLAČAN support tako s strani prodajalca hardwera kot
linux distribucije.

Tko da, Microsoftu se ni za bat. Sploh dokler lahko postavi ceno za
svoje produkte tko, da recimo od delovnega mesta tajnice pokasira
100K sit.
